I wish I could think of some, I guess having a job.
I had posirive vibes the last two years. weird how that works
cons:
We were told Bank of America is an "in the office company" which let's you know they do not give a care about their employees or how things have changed. Despite having better and more efficient production while at home during the last two years, Bank of America's management has decided you need to be in the office "just because" nevermind people still being afraid to come into work because of the virus, or rising gas prices. I guess someone's ego was being adversely impacted so they needed to make sure we capitulate. it is an absolutely tone deaf company, and does not give a hoot about the employees' welfare. HR is inept too, the stuff I know would make people cringe. 

I literally know people posting out of jobs to take less money and less stress within the bank. Management is either clueless or gutless Moynihan is tone deaf. People rather give up their position than deal with the ineptitude of management.

pros: allowed to work remotely full time
cons: I’ve worked at Bank of America as a contract for almost a year and what a nightmare it had been. I’d been put down, micromanaged on a level where I had never experienced. The leads were constantly mocking me if I was not online for more than 10 minutes, furthermore called me on my person number during doctor appointments (even during cancer screening) and told me to reschedule my doctor appointments because apparently I could not take care of my own health and was forced to comply to junior management who had absolutely no prior training working as team leads. I have been in the industry for over 22 years and that was never taken into consideration. As a contractor I was belittled on a daily basis. My company who placed me at Insight Global acted extremely unprofessional when I brought up harassment. They refused to investigate, maybe out of fear of losing a client but not their dignity. My contract abruptly ended without explanation probably because of numerous complaints about harassment. I told the managers that my mental health was being affected by all of the harassment I had to endure. Note to everyone experiencing this treatment: Do not complain directly to the managers, bring all issues to HR in a written form as managers sight will with employees.

Management for the most part has your best interest, and the salaries are competitive in nature, they could bump it up a little. I think they noticed this and have already bumped a few positions up. Over all I loved working for this company, and will continue to do so until another opportunity arrises.
cons: Changing the role towards more widget-based products, causes customers to have frustrations, as well as the banker. This is not a huge deal but does make sales a little more challenging. Also, they have rolled out a few products lately that have not been thoroughly tested and ended up hurting the brand and the employee at the same time. They push sales but the products are not even fully ready, making it difficult to sell.

job_title: Relationship Banker in New York, NY
pros: Opportunity to grow within company
cons: I got hired as a RB.I thought related to the sales position, unfortunately manipulate the title of Relationship Banker position .During the interview they did not disclose the description of my position.Bank of America RB/ Associate Banker/Universal Banker.Relationship manager title means (Personal Banker).I can say management favoritism politics.

review_title: NOT the company it used to be to work for...
pros: Job Security, good tuition reimbursement $5,250, health insurance is free under I think $50k a year (for individual)
cons: No path for advancement (its who you know), they only offer 5% 401K Match while other banks offer 6% match. Bonuses are a joke unless you are a Band 3 or 4 and again its who you know. The other banks offer bonuses 8% to even 25% (yes, Wells does that....) while BofA? 1% bonus if you're a Band 6 and most I'd ever gotten (with an exceeds rating) was...$8k. More you make, the more you pay for your health insurance. You end up paying more almost every year (they did stay flat for awhile) if you're over $70k in salary. Cost of living increases get passed on to YOU and there goes your 2% raise if you're lucky to get it.

job_title: Financial Center Manager in Memphis, TN
pros: Pay is above average Teammates you work with are hard workers and are like family
cons: Overworked!!!! Do more with less business model… meaning if you are the manager you will work tirelessly with no reward. You are expected to work and conform to their work environment. I don’t recommend drinking the Koolaid because the Koolaid burns! Because Nothing is ever good enough. You don’t have a voice. You don’t have a say in anything as a leader. You get paid really well to babysit and hand off clients. You are not leading you are baby sitting Bank of America branches. You don’t ever develop a real skill set. You walk around in fear everyday that an auditor from hell will come and find everything you do wrong as a leader and tell you how bad of leader you are. Did I mention you babysit a lobby all day. Oh maybe that’s why we can’t get some of the many task done because Oh maybe we were baby sitting the lobby. Don’t ever volunteer or agree to provide feedback. You will be labeled as a slacker or complainer. Staffing is a huge issue. If you plan to be a manager bring snacks to work. Never will you get a real lunch if you don’t have someone else to baby sit your lobby. That’s because you cannot leave any of the associates UNATTENDED that the company spent so much money on new hire and onboarding after successful background checks and finger printing. Yep that means for some reason they don’t trust the associates perhaps? The list goes on. Bank of America brags about having over 130K associates but I can confidently tell you none of them are hardly in the branches. They work the associates in the branch so hard by loading duties and tasks. You are apart of a 1 size fits all model. The branches are staffed the same irregardless of volume and traffic. Yea make it make sense…. Try explain it to your clients. Good luck! Not very client centric at all. Making their clients wait in long lines outside the branches. Shame on BOA.

job_title: Senior Fraud Analyst in Dallas, TX
pros: Good benefits if you have a family: childcare reimbursement, elderly care, maternity/paternity leave, adoption expense assistance
cons:
The 2% "cost of living raise" does not cover COL at all. Most employees are spending 50% of their paycheck on housing, if not more.

Removing work-from-home options after 2 years for "company culture" is heartbreaking for employees and their families. Especially with gas prices the way they are, this commute plus all the in-office expenses of having to buy work clothes, hand sanitizer, masks that actually work, extra car maintenance, etc. is creating a scenario where most employees are taking a sizeable pay cut.

Not to mention how bad commuting is for the mental health and environment of your employees. 

Other banks are offering more work from home/hybrid options and better pay--and many employees here are actively weighing their options to leave for elsewhere or retire. People are already on-edge and moods are notably down because of this change. Offering extra counseling sessions isn't enough.

- Unfair Politics. (Promoting professionally unfit people because of their connections instead of experienced folks with long-standing careers within the company. The outcome: unbearable micro managers and absent managers who leave their employees to run the show.)

review_title: I didn’t recognize the great company I read about on our intranet
pros:
Salary and benefits 
Flexible with remote work
cons:
Every new initiative was handled as a fire drill. This created unnecessary stress and we were never given the time to accomplish the objectives the right way. 
Leadership talks a very good game around career paths and growth opportunities but that was not my experience. 
The Bank bought Merrill Lynch in 2008 or 2009. The integration of the two investment organizations was still incomplete in 2021. This resulted in redundancies with many groups doing the same work. My group was moved from one business in wealth management to another so we were the new group without established roles. My team became the dumping ground for the work no other team wanted.  At age 57, with 30 years in private banking and year over year excellent performance , I decided I would rather walk away rather than perform ancillary functions that satisfied risk and compliance but had very little impact on the actual business of wealth management.

pros:
Good resources, great coworkers
Pay and benefits are fine, you give up some top end for the stability of the company.
cons: BofA is really shooting themselves in the foot over not embracing remote and hybrid work. They have some of the best tech tools for non-customer facing employees to use remotely, there’s really no reason to force people back in other than try to hang onto the sink costs of existing office space. This is why I left and many others I know—also why I won’t go back till they change.

review_title: Open a checking account everyday or you’re fired
job_title: Wealth Management Banking Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: Merrill is the sole pro. The advisors, them sense of team, the brand (both BOA and Merrill), hands on learning from top-producing portfolio managers
cons: -This is not a traditional private banking role. This is retail banking operating within a Merrill Lynch office. -You do not answer or report to Merrill. You report to Bank of America Consumer Bankers that likely sit in another state and have NEVER worked in your office. They largely do not understand or care about your Merrill advisors or their clients, and constantly micromanage under the threat of termination or corrective action should you not open an exorbitant number of checking accounts. This is [again], despite the fact that only two-out-of-six hundred employees are meting their goals. -Annual Specialist turnover hovers around 65%, higher in some markets, and over 90% of Wealth Management Banking markets are in the red. No one in this role is NOT counting the days until their one-year mark when they can apply out for a CA or other bank position. -Collaboration is NOT welcomed and unanimity and nepotism are a major concern. -The sole KPIs is checking accounts. Zero consideration is given to any other business development activity (credit cards, home and commercial lending, mortgages, investment balances, etc), DESPITE it falling within your purview to service and advise on such items. -Service takes a large chunk of your time each day, mainly because you do not have the same access to crucial systems as Bank of America Consumer, branch and call center employees. -Management actively works to ensure you do not find employment outside of the role. Previously the focus was on “churning and burning” bankers, but due to recent employee surveys and attrition, now emphasizing trapping bankers in their role. -Several colleagues have been written-up without any notice. These were thrown out after internal review, but those managers faced no consequence. -EOY discretionary bonus earning potential was grossly misrepresented in the interview. After landing in the top-20 percentile of Specialists, I received a bonus over 60% below what was quoted as the average. Still, I received far more than my peers. -Work life balance is nonexistent and WFH is not an option. This is partially fair, as this role was never stated to be remote, but over 90% of your teams are NOT in office. However, you will. Be honest with yourself and thoroughly map your office, commute, parking and related costs. They will be realized.

pros: Good pay and benefits are great.
cons: Very micro managing, schedule is unpredictable. Very short staff, not flexible with schedule and life events. You practically don’t have a life with this corporation.

review_title: Shell of what it used to be - now only for the "Woke"
pros: I personally get paid well for my position, but when your review is 'exceeds' and you only receive a 2% raise (when the company just had record growth), I know I'm being punished/held back so others in same role can catch up. I like my direct manager and the teams I support, but I have no control over when all that changes (and it does change often). Entry level positions will be starting at $25/hr by 2025, currently at $21.
cons: Everyone is extremely unhappy right now with raises/bonuses and there is a mass exodus, but company doesn't care. All decisions and actions are now based on the color of your skin, your vax status and your personal pronouns. No rhyme or reason to why some get promoted to management, other than playing favorites...so you will likely work under someone who should never be managing people. On my team, 2 VERY deserving females were passed over for promotions and given to 2 males (1 of which does NOT deserve it at all)...and this was done by a female manager.

review_title: Not a great place to work.
pros: Weeks of training but content could be better and more hands on should be added to the training plan. Good benefits.
cons:
Hands on training needs to have more structure. Not all current staff have the ability/skill set to be a good trainer/Mentor. 

Over worked and under paid.

While still in training, I was bouncing back and forth from the teller side and platform side with no break.  Current staff and manager would take long smoke breaks every hour, while non-smokers were not permitted appropriate breaks and many times denied a lunch break. 

Assistant manager was not motivated to help clients or other staff and only did the bear minimum (her words). 

Typically worked 6 days a week, while others got a day off of their choosing. 

Rules only apply when it benefits the leadership.  Leadership constantly asked me to take short cuts and not follow protocol. But when a finding happens, it’s all your fault.  

Pay is not enough for the amount of work/responsibilities.

review_title: Politics, Low salary, Low Hikes, No Growth
pros: Only a brand name. That to logically BA continuum (non-bank subsidiary), not Bank of America
cons:
Have nice policies on paper, but they are only for US. Like 4 month paternity (10days for India), People manager will use your ideas for their own growth, Extream level of favouritism, Stocks as success reward/bonus (18-20k annual bonus for India), 20-30% annual growth (3-10% hike in India), Very big pay disparity (Eg-200 crore annual salary to CEO Mr Brian, 31% hike in 2021, India employees get peanuts), No welcome gift in form of Joining kit etc. (I joined in lockdown, received 10 pieces of Mask and one sanitizer, it made my roommates laugh on me), unsupportive Indian management (I purchased laptop to work from home at my own and then have to wait for 11 months for reimbursement) 
In short, it's only a name which can give you feeling of working in a big brand, otherwise nothing at India office is worth to mention as benefits for BOA.

pros: -good canteen (though quite expensive) with great staff going above and beyond to serve good food and dishes; they also prepare special dishes/cakes for Halloween etc.
cons:
-salary increase falls short of inflation,
-shares instead of monetary incentive that could be invested elsewhere,
-mild culture of xenophobic attitudes (mocking someone's English by repeatedly mentioning the mistake they make or used to make, making jokes based on race/ethnicity...) with no reaction after incidents were reported or raised as an issue,
-very little diversity at a senior level (almost all are white straight British men),
-limited career progression opportunities,
-poor office facilities (too few cleaners combined with some messy colleagues in a busy office),
-no remote work options,
-poor handling of the pandemic (denial in first two months, poor adherence to pandemic, no monitoring of rule adherence amongst employees...),
-senior management trying to ban discussion of salaries amongst staff,
-salary bands/levels are not transparent,
-you may occasionally get asked about doing something that is unlawful or unethical (I reported these few occasions to the police and received support from there),
-poor environmental commitment (EV subsidy not available for most electric cars, office using powerful greenhouse gas as an insulator, the pension scheme does not have an option to invest in decarbonised funds...),
-the bank funded an award event for a far right politician Jair Bolsonaro while claiming to support BAME and LGBT communities.

job_title: Business Support Lead II in Phoenix, AZ
pros: I've had an incredible journey so far in my career with this company. The culture is demanding yet I've had the flexibility to maintain a reasonable work life balance. I've worked for different types of managers and while some did not align with my personality, I've had many who did. Great benefits and fair pay with lots of opportunity for diversity and inclusion. Overall I've enjoyed this company and have reaped the benefits. There is childcare reimbursements that helps with costs of daycare, tuition reimbursement, vacation, sick time and pto, 401k and financial education.
cons: There is a lot of change as far as regulatory and organizational restructuring which is typical for this industry. It requires someone who embraces change and can quickly pivot from one project to another. While it can be rewarding, you may experience burnout if you do not pace yourself. I've known some people who have had a terrible time in their roles due to bosses who create toxic workplaces. There is a minimum time frame required to move to a different team. If you can wait out that requirement, you have a whole world of other opportunities that you can apply for.

pros: Great benefits, health, dental, vision tuition reimbursement, 16 weeks of maternity/ paternity leave, sick days and ample vacation time varies with band level. BofA is well-known brand, established brand (versus a start-up). Several affinity/employee resource groups to get involved with. Finally replaced outdated leaders with new more promising leaders. Commitment to raise minimum pay to $21.
cons: Confusing, job descriptions. Middle management needs a complete overhaul and is filled with poor managers and their proteges that act and think the same way. Touts awards for "Diversity" yet company lacks ethnic and cultural diversity in Senior and Middle Management. Culture supports favoritism and mostly white men in executive roles and middle management. "You remind me of myself when I was younger" culture .....results in less hiring/promotion of People of Color and more hiring/promotion/mentorship of white men and women regardless of their background or experience. Zero transparency around the promotion process. External hires with no experience are paid more than "tenured" employees with direct experience. Company refuses to disclose pay/promotion/hiring stats to public. Public commitments made to address external social issues, but no changes are being made to address internal inequities in hiring, promotion and professional development.

review_title: Decent benefits but not enough appreciation for employees
pros:
Decent enough benefits and base pay. Pretty standard amongst the larger financial institutions. I actually really liked this job for the first year. Even during the height of the pandemic the bank provided a lot of great temporary benefits that made working during that time a lot less stressful.

The bank does a lot of work to be inclusive and diverse. Every center at worked at had people of all different backgrounds.

The bank has many groups that you can join that encourage diversity and inclusion. These groups did a lot of community outreach.

All in all, it's a good job IF you can deal with all the stress and anxiety that come along with it.
cons:
The bank really shot themselves in the foot during the pandemic in the long run. Incentives were frozen which caused a lot of people to leave and the people who were left didn't receive near the recognition they deserved for keeping their centers up and running. This caused even more people to leave making it even harder for the people who stayed. Employees are constantly shuffled to other centers just to meet the bare minimum staff requirements. Many centers run on three maybe four people. 40+ hour, 6 day weeks are the norm.

The heavy work load means that any plans for career development within the firm are put on the back burner.

There is a constant push for online and mobile banking which can leave less tech savvy clientele out in the cold. Access to tools to assist with client issues at the center is constantly pushed to the back office side which means a lot of your interactions will be spent on hold trying to get a hold of someone for even the most basic problems.

Senior management often misses the forest through the trees.

review_title: Honest Review of 5-year stint with positives and negatives
pros:
Solid benefits, great exposure, for a bank - a strong brand and community reputation, philanthropy. 
Networking- you can literally reach out and meet with anyone to meet for coffee, etc. 

You can get involved in a lot of extracurriculars supported by the bank which is nice.
cons:
Like any big company- your management team can make your life great or miserable. Unfortunately, my experience was the latter:

-despite exceptional (exceeds/exceeds) peformance, minimal pay raises (1.8-2.1%) with no transparency on the compensation formula. 

-watching 50-year old managers have panic attacks over a slide deck about some non critical topic.

-always being promised a promotion to the next band level due to exceptional performance, but never following through despite being persistent 

- below average stock bonus and no ESPP

I’m sure there are plenty of managers who create a positive environment but after 5 years several of my peers have similar feelings.

There is always (always) a very urgent /emergency push to produce any deliverables , despite how menial the task. Everything is an emergency.
